proof:
Let $k = |V_G(\gamma)|$. By assumption, $k \ge \frac{A \log n}{d}$. We want to show that $w^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma) \le q^{1-k/10}$. The weight is given by $w^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma) = \prod_{i \in V_G(\gamma)} w_i^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma)$, where $w_i^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma) = \frac{q^{\deg_{G_F}(i)/2}}{Z_i^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma)}$ and $Z_i^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma) = \sum_{\sigma_i \in \{\pm 1\}} q^{\sigma_i h_i^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma)/2} = 2 \cosh(h_i^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma) \ln(q)/2)$. The field $h_i^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma)$ is given by $h_i^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma) = \sum_{j \in \partial_G i \setminus V_G(\gamma)} J_{ij} \sigma_j$. Let $S_i = \partial_G i \setminus V_G(\gamma)$. Whp, for all $i \in V$, $\deg_G(i) \in [d/2, 3d/2]$. Also, $\deg_{G_F}(i) \le 2\Delta-2$. Thus for $d$ large enough, $|S_i| = \deg_G(i) - \deg_{G_F}(i) \ge d/2 - (2\Delta-2) \ge d/3$. The variables $J_{ij}\sigma_j$ for $j \in S_i$ are i.i.d. Rademacher random variables. Thus, by a Chernoff bound on the sum $h_i^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma)$, for any $i \in V_G(\gamma)$,
$$ \mathbb{P}[|h_i^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma)| \le d/4] \le 2 \exp(-|S_i|/32) \le 2 \exp(-d/32) $$
for $d$ large enough, because $|S_i| \ge d/2$ whp. Let $\mathcal{E}_i$ be the event that $|h_i^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma)| > d/4$. Let $I_0 = \{i \in V_G(\gamma) : \mathcal{E}_i \text{ fails}\}$.
Let $X_i$ be the indicator variable for the event $\mathcal{E}_i^c$. Then $\mathbb{E}[X_i] \le 2e^{-d/32}$ for all $i \in V_G(\gamma)$. Since the variables $\{X_i\}_{i \in V_G(\gamma)}$ are independent, we can apply a Chernoff bound to their sum $|I_0| = \sum_{i \in V_G(\gamma)} X_i$.
By a Chernoff bound (cf. Theorem A.1.4 in [1]), for any $\delta > 0$, $\mathbb{P}[|I_0| \ge (1+\delta)\mathbb{E}[|I_0|]] \le \exp(-\delta^2 \mathbb{E}[|I_0|]/3)$. We have $\mathbb{E}[|I_0|] = \sum_{i \in V_G(\gamma)} \mathbb{E}[X_i] \le k \cdot 2e^{-d/32}$. For $d$ large enough, $\mathbb{E}[|I_0|]$ is very small. Let's choose $\delta$ such that $(1+\delta)\mathbb{E}[|I_0|] = k/10$. This gives $\delta = \frac{k/10}{\mathbb{E}[|I_0|]} - 1 \ge \frac{k/10}{2ke^{-d/32}} - 1 = \frac{e^{d/32}}{20} - 1$. For $d$ large, this $\delta$ is large. The probability of failure is then bounded by $\exp(-\delta^2 \mathbb{E}[|I_0|]/3) \approx \exp(-(\frac{e^{d/32}}{20})^2 \cdot 2ke^{-d/32}/3) = \exp(-\Omega(k e^{d/32}))$, which is vanishingly small. Thus, with high probability, $|I_0| \le k/10$.
We can now bound the weight $w^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma)$. We split the vertices $V_G(\gamma)$ into $I_0$ and $V_G(\gamma) \setminus I_0$. For the vertices $i \in V_G(\gamma) \setminus I_0$, we have $|h_i^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma)| > d/4$. For these vertices,
$$ w_i^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma) = \frac{q^{\deg_{G_F}(i)/2}}{2 \cosh(h_i^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma) \ln(q)/2)} \le \frac{1}{2} \exp(-|h_i^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma)||\ln(q)|/2) \le \frac{1}{2} \exp(-d/8 |\ln q|). $$
For the vertices $i \in I_0$, of which there are at most $k/10$, we use the trivial bound $w_i^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma) \le q^{-(\Delta-1)}$ (from Lemma B.1).
Putting these together,
$$ w^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma) \le (q^{-(\Delta-1)})^{k/10} \left(\frac{1}{2} \exp(-d/8 |\ln q|)\right)^{9k/10} = q^{-(\Delta-1)k/10} \exp\left(-\frac{9k}{10}\left(\ln 2 + \frac{d}{8}|\ln q|\right)\right). $$
Using the assumption $k \ge \frac{A \log n}{d}$, we have $dk \ge A \log n$.
$$ w^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma) \le q^{-(\Delta-1)k/10} \exp\left(-\frac{9k \ln 2}{10}\right) \exp\left(-\frac{9 A \log n}{80}|\ln q|\right) = q^{-(\Delta-1)k/10} \left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{9k/10} n^{-9A|\ln q|/80}. $$
We want to show this is less than $q^{1-k/10}$. This is equivalent to
$$ q^{-(\Delta-2)k/10} \left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{9k/10} n^{-9A|\ln q|/80} \le q. $$
For $d$ large enough, $\Delta$ is bounded, and $k$ can be large. For $A$ large enough, the $n^{-9A|\ln q|/80}$ term dominates and makes the LHS smaller than the RHS. This completes the proof.
